words.ENTRY: <H>hair</H><audio>hair.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><NR>1.</NR><bracket>countable</bracket><D>one of the long thin things that grow on the skin of people and animals:</D> <X>There's a hair in my soup.</X><dot><X>The dog left hairs all over the furniture.</X><NR>2.</NR><bracket>uncountable</bracket><D>the mass of hairs on a person's head:</D> <X>He has short black hair.</X>

hangverb(past, past participle hung) to attach something or be attached at the top so that the lower part is free or loose: Hang your coat on the hook.I hung the wash on the line. hang out (slang) to spend time in a place, often without doing very much: I usually just hang out with my friends after school.

<H>happy</H><audio>happy.mp3</audio><PS>adjective</PS>(<DR>happier</DR>; <DR>happiest</DR>) <NR>1.</NR><D>feeling, showing or giving pleasure or satisfaction:</D> <X>a happy childhood</X><dot><X>a happy family</X><dot><X>The movie is sad, but it has a happy ending.</X><NR>2.</NR><D>(used in greetings to wish somebody an enjoyable time):</D> <X>Happy Birthday!</X><dot><X>Happy New Year!</X>

hardworkingadjectiveworking with effort and energy:
a hardworking student
<H>hat</H><audio>hat.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a covering that you wear on your head, usually when you are outside:</D> <X>to wear a hat</X>
<H>hate</H><audio>hate.mp3</audio><PS>verb</PS><D>to have a very strong feeling of dislike (for somebody/something):</D> <X>I hate grapefruit.</X><dot><X>He hates driving at night.</X>

have1verb(third person singular has; past, past participle had) 1.to own or possess: I have a new camera.They don't have a car.The apartment has two bedrooms.Do you have any brothers or sisters?2.to be sick with something: She has a bad cold.to have the flu/a headache3.(used with many nouns to talk about doing something): What time do you have breakfast?to have a cup of coffee/a sandwichWe're having a meeting next week.4.(used with many nouns to talk about experiencing something): Have a nice day!to have fun/a good timeto have an accident/a heart attack/an operationhave2auxiliary verb(used for forming perfect tenses): I've already seen this program.She's been in the US for six months.Jim hasn't written to me yet.Have you been waiting long?

<H>he</H><audio>he.mp3</audio><PS>pronoun</PS><D>(the subject of a verb) the male person or animal mentioned earlier or being observed now:</D> <X>I talked to John before he left.</X><dot><X>Look at that little boy! He's going to fall!</X>

hear (past, past participle heard) (not used in the continuous forms) to receive sounds with your ears: Can you speak a little louder? I don't hear very well.Sorry I'm late. I didn't hear my alarm clock this morning.

<H>heavy</H><audio>heavy.mp3</audio><PS>adjective</PS>(<DR>heavier</DR>; <DR>heaviest</DR>) <NR>1.</NR><D>weighing a lot, and difficult to lift or move:</D> <X>This box is too heavy for me to carry.</X><NR>2.</NR><D>(used about a person) fat:</D> <X>Donna's gotten a little heavier since the last time I saw her.</X>

<H>heel</H><audio>heel.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><NR>1.</NR><D>the back part of the foot:</D> <X>The back of these shoes rub against my heels.</X><NR>2.</NR><D>the raised part of a shoe under the heel of your foot:</D> <X>high heels</X> (= shoes with high heels)

<H>hello</H><audio>hello.mp3</audio><PS>interjection</PS><D>(used for greeting somebody, to attract somebody's attention, or when you are using the telephone):</D> <X>Hello, how are you?</X><dot><X>Hello, is anybody there?</X>

<H>her</H><su>1</su><audio>her.mp3</audio><PS>pronoun</PS><D>(the object of a verb or preposition) a female person or animal that was mentioned earlier or is being observed now:</D> <X>He told Sue that he loved her.</X><dot><X>I have a letter for your mother. Could you give it to her for me?</X><H>her</H><su>2</su><audio>her.mp3</audio><PS>determiner</PS><D>belonging to a female person or animal that was mentioned earlier or is being observed now:</D> <X>That's her book. She left it there this morning.</X><dot><X>Lynn broke her leg.</X>

<H>here</H><audio>here.mp3</audio><PS>adverb</PS>(after a verb or a preposition) <D>in, at, or to the place where you are:</D> <X>I live here.</X><dot><X>Come (over) here.</X><dot><X>The school is a mile from here.</X><dot><X>Please sign here.</X>
heyinterjection(informal) (used when you want to attract somebody's attention or to show that you are surprised or interested): Hey, what are you doing?Hey, I like your bike!
hiinterjection(informal) (used as a greeting when you meet somebody) "Rob, this is my friend Laura Kwan." "Hi, nice to meet you."

<H>him</H><audio>him.mp3</audio><PS>pronoun</PS><D>(the object of a verb or preposition) a male person or animal that was mentioned earlier or is being observed now:</D> <X>Louise told Joe that she loved him.</X><dot><X>I have a letter for your father. Can you give it to him for me?</X><dot><X>That must be him now.</X>

his1 (strong form) determinerbelonging to a male person or animal that was mentioned earlier or is being observed now: That's his book. He left it there this morning.Matthew hurt his shoulder.his2pronounof or belonging to him: This is my book, so that one must be his.My dad has a lot of ties, so I borrowed one of his.

holdverb(past, past participle held) 1.to take somebody/
something and keep him/her/it in your hand, etc.: He held a photo in his hand.The woman was holding a baby in her arms.Hold my hand. This is a busy street.2.to keep something in a certain position: Hold your head up straight.Hold the camera still or you'll spoil the picture.

home1noun1.countable, uncountablethe place where you live (with your family) or where you feel that you belong: uncountableShe left home at the age of 21.2.countablea house, an apartment, etc.: Sales of new homes rose by 3% last year. at home1.in your house, apartment, etc.: We bought a computer so that Jackie can work at home.Nick is 28 years old, but he still lives at home. (= with his parents) 2.as if you were in your own home; comfortable: Please make yourself at home.They were warm and welcoming and I felt at home right away.home2adverbat, in, or to your home or home country:
We stopped at Jack and Terri's house, but they weren't home.We should go home soon.She'll be flying home for the holidays.
<H>homework</H><audio>homework.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>uncountable</bracket><D>the work that teachers give to students to do away from school:</D> <X>to do your homework</X>

<H>hope</H><audio>hope.mp3</audio><PS>verb </PS><CF>hope (for something)</CF>; <CF>hope to do something</CF>; <CF>hope (that) something will happen</CF> <D>to want something to happen or be true:</D> <X>We're hoping for sunny weather tomorrow.</X><dot><X>I hope (that) you feel better soon.</X><dot><X>I'm hoping to buy a car this summer.</X>
<H>hospital</H><audio>hospital.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a place where sick or injured people are treated:</D> <X>He was rushed to the hospital in an ambulance.</X>

hotelnouncountablea place where you pay to sleep (and perhaps eat your meals) when you are on vacation or traveling:
to stay at/in a hotelto reserve a hotel room

<H>hour</H><audio>hour.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><NR>1.</NR><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a period of 60 minutes:</D> <X>He worked for three hours after dinner.</X><dot><X>The program lasts about half an hour.</X><dot><X>I waited there for hours.</X><NR>2.</NR><bracket>countable, uncountable</bracket><D>a period of time:</D> <bracket>countable</bracket><X>I'm going shopping on my lunch hour.</X><dot><bracket>uncountable</bracket><X>The traffic is very bad during rush hour.</X>
housenouncountable(plural houses) a building that is made for one family to live in: a three-bedroom house

<H>how</H><su>1</su><audio>how.mp3</audio><PS>adverb</PS><NR>1.</NR><D>(used in questions) in what way:</D> <X>How do you spell your name?</X><dot><X>Can you show me how to use this machine?</X><NR>2.</NR><D>(used when you are asking about somebody's health):</D> <X>"How is your mother?" "She's feeling a lot better now."</X><NR>3.</NR><D>(used when you are asking about a thing or a situation):</D> <X>How was the weather?</X><dot><X>How is your meal?</X><NR>4.</NR><D>(used in questions before an adjective or adverb when you are asking about the degree, amount, age, etc. of somebody/something):</D> <X>How old are you?</X><dot><X>How much is that?</X><dot><X>How long did it take to get here? </X><CF>how/what about ...?</CF><NR>1.</NR><D>(used when asking for information about somebody/something or for somebody's opinion or wish):</D> <X>I'm going to have chicken. How about you?</X><dot><X>How about Ruth? What's she doing?</X><NR>2.</NR><D>(used when making a suggestion):</D> <X>How about going to a movie tonight?</X><H>how</H><su>2</su><audio>how.mp3</audio><PS>conjunction</PS><D>the way in which:</D> <X>I can't remember how to get there.</X>
<H>huge</H><audio>huge.mp3</audio><PS>adjective</PS><D>very large:</D> <X>I have a huge amount of work to do.</X><dot><X>a huge building</X>
<H>hungry</H><audio>hungry.mp3</audio><PS>adjective</PS>(<DR>hungrier</DR>; <DR>hungriest</DR>) <D>wanting to eat:</D> <X>I'm hungry. Let's eat soon.</X>

<H>husband</H><audio>husband.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a man that a woman is married to:</D> <X>a good husband and father</X><dot><X>She and her husband have been married for 18 years.</X>
